title:
Dedekind-MacNeille and related completions: subfitness, regularity, and
  Booleanness

sections.text:
#### Abstract

Completions play an important rôle for studying structure by supplying elements that in some sense "ought to be." Among these, the Dedekind-MacNeille completion is of particular importance. In 1968 Janowitz provided necessary and sufficient conditions for it to be subfit or Boolean. Another natural separation axiom connected to these is regularity. We explore similar characterizations of when closely related completions are subfit, regular, or Boolean. We are mainly interested in the Bruns-Lakser, ideal, and canonical completions, which (unlike the Dedekind-MacNeille completion) satisfy stronger forms of distributivity. The first two are widely used in pointfree topology, while the latter is of crucial importance in the semantics of modal logic.

## CONTENTS

1. Introduction 1
2. Preliminaries 4
3. The proHeyting extension 7
4. Subfitness 11
5. Regularity 16
6. Booleanness 24
7. Conclusion with summary 26

References 28

## 1. INTRODUCTION

As is well known, separation properties play an important rôle in classifying topological spaces. They have also been investigated in the pointfree setting; see the recent monograph [PP21]. Among these, subfitness is a particularly important lower separation axiom. It is closely related to $\mathrm{T}_{1}$-separation (a topological space is $\mathrm{T}_{1}$ iff it is $\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{D}}$ and the lattice of open sets is subfit; see, e.g., [PP21, p. 24]). Subfitness originated in the work of Wallman [Wal38] in its dual form under the name of disjunctivity (using the lattice of closed sets of a topological space). It was further studied by Büchi [Bü48] and Pierce [Pie54]. In the

[^0]
[^0]:    2020 Mathematics Subject Classification. 54D10; 18F70; 06D22; 06B23; 06B15; 06D50; 06E15.
    Key words and phrases. Separation axioms; distributive lattice; frame; subfit; regular; Boolean; DedekindMacNeille completion; Priestley duality.

modern form (using the lattice of open sets) it was explored by Simmons [Sim78] under the name of conjunctivity. In set theory, disjunctivity is known as separativity and plays an important rôle in forcing; see [Kun11, pp.199-200].

To distinguish these two notions, we refer to them as $\vee$-subfitness and $\wedge$-subfitness, but suppress $\vee$ from the former when no confusion arises. Subfitness is usually defined for frames, that is, complete lattices in which finite meets distribute over arbitrary joins, as these provide a natural generalization of lattices of open sets [PP12]. However, they also make perfect sense for arbitrary bounded lattices. We thus define a bounded lattice A to be $\vee$-subfit if

$$
\forall a, b\{a \not \leq b \Longrightarrow \exists c: a \vee c=1 \neq b \vee c\}
$$

and $\wedge$-subfit if

$$
\forall a, b\{a \not \leq b \Longrightarrow \exists c: a \wedge c \neq 0=b \wedge c)
$$

Our starting point is the following noteworthy observation of Janowitz [Jan68]:

- A bounded lattice A is $\vee$-subfit (resp. $\wedge$-subfit) iff its Dedekind-MacNeille completion $\mathcal{D}$ MA is $\vee$-subfit (resp. $\wedge$-subfit).
- $\mathcal{D}$ MA is Boolean iff A is distributive, $\vee$-subfit, and $\wedge$-subfit.

While $\mathcal{D M A}$ has many desirable properties, it is not always distributive (see, e.g., [BD74, Sec. XII.2]). This can be remedied by considering the injective hull (of a $\wedge$-semilattice) constructed by Bruns and Lakser [BL70] (see also Horn and Kimura [HK71]), which is always a frame. We call it the Bruns-Lakser completion and denote by $\mathcal{B} \mathcal{L} A$. It is natural to consider the same questions for $\mathcal{B} \mathcal{L} A$ as Janowitz considered for $\mathcal{D M A}$. This is one of our main aims in this work. Additionally, we consider two other well-studied completions, the ideal completion $\mathcal{I}$ A and the canonical completion $A^{\sigma}$, and consider the same questions for them. The ideal completion gives the free frame over a distributive lattice, making it an important construction in frame theory [Joh82], whereas the canonical completion ${ }^{1}$ plays an important rôle in Kripke completeness of modal logics [BdRV01].

Another well-known separation axiom is regularity. For frames it is situated between subfit and Boolean. We recall that a frame is regular if

$$
\forall a, b\{a \not \leq b \Longrightarrow \exists c: c \prec a \& c \not \leq b\}
$$

where $\prec$ is the rather below relation (see Section 5 for details). Again, this condition makes perfect sense for arbitrary bounded lattices, however distributivity is required to prove that regularity implies subfitness. Because of this, in this paper we concentrate on distributive lattices. The general case will be studied in a forthcoming paper. Thus, the main goal of this paper is to investigate when the four completions $\mathcal{D M A}, \mathcal{B} \mathcal{L} A, \mathcal{I} A$, and $A^{\sigma}$ of a bounded distributive lattice $A$ are subfit, regular, or Boolean. We will also study when these properties are preserved/reflected by these four completions. For this, as expected, counterexamples play an important rôle. These are often more efficiently described (not to mention discovered) by looking at the Priestley dual. Thus, Priestley duality for distributive lattices, which represents each distributive lattice as the lattice of

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ It is more commonly known as the canonical extension, but in this context it is convenient to use a uniform term to describe all four constructions.

clopen upsets of a Priestley space (see Section 2 for details), is one of main tools of this work.

As we will see in Section 2, we have the poset embeddings

$$
\mathrm{A} \hookrightarrow \mathcal{D} \mathcal{M} A \hookrightarrow \mathcal{B} \mathcal{L} A \hookrightarrow \mathcal{J} A \hookrightarrow \mathrm{~A}^{\sigma} .
$$

Thus, $\mathcal{D} \mathcal{M} A$ is the "closest" completion to $A$. As we pointed out above, Janowitz showed that $\mathcal{D} \mathcal{M} A$ is subfit iff $A$ is subfit. In addition, we describe when subfitness is preserved and/or reflected by a lattice extension, yielding Janowitz's result as a corollary. On the other hand, since $\mathcal{D} \mathcal{M} A$ may not be distributive, the issue of regularity for $\mathcal{D} \mathcal{M} A$ is more complicated (see the previous paragraph). We thus assume that $\mathcal{D} \mathcal{M} A$ is distributive. In this case, we show that $\mathcal{D} \mathcal{M} A$ is regular iff $\mathcal{B} \mathcal{L} A$ is regular and $A$ is subfit.

For a distributive lattice A, Janowitz proved that $\mathcal{D} \mathcal{M} A$ is Boolean iff $A$ is both $\vee$-subit and $\wedge$-subfit. We prove that $\mathcal{B} \mathcal{L} A$ is Boolean iff $A$ is $\wedge$-subfit, hence obtaining Janowitz's other result as a corollary. We also characterize when $\mathcal{B} \mathcal{L} A$ is subfit and when $\mathcal{B} \mathcal{L} A$ is regular. Each turns out to be strictly weaker than the corresponding property of $A$, and we provide necessary and sufficient conditions for when these two conditions are reflected. On the one hand, this relates to the notion of a proHeyting lattice; on the other hand, it results in a stronger notion of regularity for $\mathcal{B} \mathcal{L} A$.

ProHeyting lattices were introduced in [BPWW16] to characterize when the DedekindMacNeille completion of a distributive lattice is a frame. This plays an important rôle in our considerations. For each distributive lattice $A$, we introduce its proHeyting extension $p \mathcal{J}(A$ and show that $\mathcal{B} \mathcal{L} A$ is exactly the Dedekind-MacNeille completion of $p \mathcal{J}(A$. We think of $p \mathcal{J}(A$ as a "finitary" version of $\mathcal{B} \mathcal{L} A$, and show that whether $\mathcal{B} \mathcal{L} A$ is subfit, regular, or Boolean depends on whether the corresponding properties hold for $p \mathcal{J}(A$.

As we will see, the three separation axioms of subfitness, regularity, and Booleanness all collapse for the canonical completion $A^{\sigma}$ and are equivalent to $A$ being Boolean. While for the ideal completion $\mathcal{J} A$, to be Boolean requires the much stronger condition that $A$ is a finite Boolean algebra. As with $A^{\sigma}$, for $\mathcal{J} A$ to be regular is equivalent to $A$ being Boolean, however the ideal completion is more sensitive with respect to subfitness. Indeed, $\mathcal{J} A$ is subfit iff every ideal is an intersection of maximal ideals, a condition that is strictly stronger than subfitness of $A$, but weaker than $A$ being Boolean.

Utilizing Priestley duality, we characterize these three separation axioms for each of the completions by identifying an appropriate density property. For example, subfitness of $A$ is equivalent to the minimal spectrum of $A$ being dense in its Priestley space $X$, while subfitness of $\mathcal{J} A$ is equivalent to to the density of the minimal spectrum of $A$ in the Skula topology of the topology of open upsets of X (see Section 4 for details).

It is natural to continue this line of research by considering other separation axioms as well as other completions. From a purely lattice-theoretic perspective, it is also of interest to explore the non-distributive setting, which we aim to do in the future.

# 2. Preliminaries 

We start by recalling that a completion of a poset $P$ is a pair ( $C, e)$ where $C$ is a complete lattice and $e: P \rightarrow C$ is a poset embedding. As is customary, we identify $P$ with its image $\mathrm{e}[\mathrm{P}]$ in C , and refer to C as a completion of P .

We say that P is join-dense in C if each element of C is a join from P , and define P being meet-dense in C similarly. Up to isomorphism, each poset P has a unique completion C such that P is both join- and meet-dense in C (see, e.g., [BD74, p. 237]). It is known as the Dedekind-MacNeille completion of P and we denote it by $\mathcal{D M P}$. While $\mathcal{D M P}$ has many desirable properties (for example, $\mathcal{D M P}$ is the injective hull of P in the category Pos of posets and order-preserving maps), it may fail to be distributive. This can be remedied by considering injective hulls in the category MSLat of $\wedge$-semilattices. These were constructed by Bruns and Lakser [BL70] (see also Horn and Kimura [HK71]), who showed that the injective hull of each $\wedge$-semilattice $S$ is a frame ${ }^{2}$ in which $S$ is join-dense. We denote this completion by $\mathcal{B} \mathcal{L} S$.

In this paper we are mainly interested in bounded distributive lattices, so we let DLat be the category of bounded distributive lattices and bounded lattice homomorphisms. For $A \in$ DLat, in addition to the Dedekind-MacNeille completion $\mathcal{D M A}$ and the Bruns-Lakser completion $\mathcal{B} \mathcal{L} A$, we consider the ideal completion $\mathcal{I A}$ (see, e.g., [Joh82, p. 59]) and the canonical completion $A^{\sigma}$ (see, e.g., [Gol89, GJ94]). As follows from the name, $\mathcal{I A}$ is the frame of all ideals of $A$, and the assignment $A \mapsto \mathcal{I} A$ defines a functor from DLat to the category Frm of frames (yielding an equivalence between DLat and the (non-full) subcategory CohFrm of Frm consisting of coherent frames; see, e.g., [Joh82, p. 65]). On the other hand, $A^{\sigma}$ is, up to isomorphism, a unique completion of $A$ that is both compact and dense [GH01, p. 349]. Moreover, the assignment $A \mapsto A^{\sigma}$ defines a functor from DLat to the category CDLat of completely distributive lattices (see, e.g., [GH01, Thm. 5.4] or [BHJ21, Cor. 2.2]).

We next characterize each of these four completions using Priestley duality for DLat [Pri70, Pri72].

Definition 2.1. A Priestley space is a compact space $X$ equipped with a partial order $\leqslant$ satisfying the Priestley separation axiom:

$$
\text { if } x \nless y \text {, then there is a clopen upset } U \text { such that } x \in U \text { and } y \notin U \text {. }
$$

Remark 2.2. The Priestley separation axiom implies that the topology has a basis of clopen sets. Thus, the topology of a Priestley space is a Stone topology (compact Hausdorff and zero-dimensional).

A Priestley morphism between Priestley spaces is a continuous order-preserving map. Let Pries be the category of Priestley spaces and Priestley morphisms.

Theorem 2.3 (Priestley duality). DLat is dually equivalent to Pries.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{2}$ We refer the reader to [Joh82] or [PP12] for all basics about frame/locale theory.

Remark 2.4. The contravariant functors establishing Priestley duality are constructed as follows. For a Priestley space $X$, let $L(X)$ be the lattice of clopen upsets of $X$, and for a Priestley morphism $f: X \rightarrow Y$ let $L(f)=f^{-1}: L(Y) \rightarrow L(X)$. For a bounded distributive lattice $A$, let $\mathcal{S}(A)$ be the poset of prime filters of $A$ and let $s_{A}: A \rightarrow \wp(\mathcal{S}(A))$ be the Stone map given by $s_{A}(a)=\{x \in \mathcal{S}(A): a \in x\}$. We order $\mathcal{S}(A)$ by inclusion and topologize it by the subbasis

$$
\left\{\mathfrak{s}_{A}(a): a \in A\right\} \cup\left\{s_{A}(b)^{c}: b \in A\right\}
$$

Then $\mathcal{S}(A)$ is a Priestley space. Moreover, if $h: A \rightarrow B$ is a bounded lattice morphism, then $\mathcal{S}(h)=h^{-1}: \mathcal{S}(B) \rightarrow \mathcal{S}(A)$ is a Priestley morpism. These two contravariant functors $L, \mathcal{S}$ establish Priestley duality. In particular, $s_{A}: A \rightarrow L \mathcal{S}(A)$ is a lattice isomorphism natural in each coordinate and $\varepsilon_{X}: X \rightarrow \mathcal{S} L(X)$, given by $\varepsilon_{X}(x)=\{U \in L(X): x \in U\}$, is an order-homeomorphism natural in each coordinate.

Remark 2.5. Priestley duality depends on the Boolean Prime Ideal Theorem (or one of its equivalents), which is a consequence of the Axiom of Choice. Thus, all of our results that depend on Priestley duality are not choice free.

We will freely use the following well-known facts about Priestley spaces (see, e.g., [DP02, pp. 258-259]):
Fact 2.6. Let X be a Priestley space.
(1) $\{\mathrm{U} \backslash \mathrm{V}: \mathrm{U}, \mathrm{V}$ clopen upsets $\}$ forms a basis for the topology on X .
(2) Open upsets (resp. downsets) are unions of clopen upsets (resp. downsets).
(3) Closed upsets (resp. downsets) are intersections of clopen upsets (resp. downsets).
(4) $\leqslant$ is a closed subset of the product $X^{2}$. Consequently, $\uparrow F$ and $\downarrow F$ are closed for each closed subset F of X .

Each Priestley space X carries a Stone topology, as well as the topology of open upsets and the topology of open downsets, the former being the join of the latter two. We write cl and int for the closure and interior in the Stone topology, $\mathrm{cl}_{1}$ and $\operatorname{int}_{1}$ for the closure and interior in the topology of open upsets, and $\mathrm{cl}_{2}$ and $\operatorname{int}_{2}$ for the closure and interior in the topology of open downsets. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{cl}_{1}(\mathrm{~S})=\downarrow \mathrm{cl}(\mathrm{~S}) ; \quad \mathrm{cl}_{2}(\mathrm{~S})=\uparrow \mathrm{cl}(\mathrm{~S}) ; \\
& \operatorname{int}_{1}(\mathrm{~S})=X \backslash \downarrow(X \backslash \operatorname{int}(\mathrm{~S})) ; \quad \operatorname{int}_{2}(\mathrm{~S})=X \backslash \uparrow(\mathrm{X} \backslash \operatorname{int}(\mathrm{~S}) \text { ). }
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore,

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
x \in \mathrm{cl}_{1}(\mathrm{~S}) \text { iff } \uparrow x \cap \mathrm{cl}(\mathrm{~S}) \neq \varnothing ; & x \in \mathrm{cl}_{2}(\mathrm{~S}) \text { iff } \downarrow x \cap \mathrm{cl}(\mathrm{~S}) \neq \varnothing \\
x \in \operatorname{int}_{1}(\mathrm{~S}) \text { iff } \uparrow x \subseteq \operatorname{int}(\mathrm{~S}) ; & x \in \operatorname{int}_{2}(\mathrm{~S}) \text { iff } \downarrow x \subseteq \operatorname{int}(\mathrm{~S})
\end{array}
$$

We are ready to characterize $A^{o}$ and $\mathcal{J} A$ in the language of Priestley spaces. For a Priestley space $X$, let $\operatorname{Up}(X)$ be the completely distributive lattice of upsets and $\operatorname{OpUp}(X)$ the frame of open upsets of $X$. We then have:

Theorem 2.7. Let $A \in$ DLat and $X$ be the Priestley space of $A$.
(1) [Gol89, GJ94] $A^{o} \cong \operatorname{Up}(X)$.

(2) $[\operatorname{Pri} 70] \mathcal{J A} \cong \operatorname{OpUp}(X)$.

Remark 2.8.
(1) Alternatively, $A^{\sigma}$ can be described as follows. Let $\mathcal{F}(A)$ be the frame of filters of $A$. Then there is a Galois connection $(\phi, \psi)$ between the powersets of $\mathcal{F}(A)$ and $\mathcal{J}(A)$ given by

$$
\phi(Y)=\{I \in \mathcal{J}(A): I \cap F \neq \varnothing \forall F \in Y\}
$$

and

$$
\psi(\mathrm{Z})=\{\mathrm{F} \in \mathcal{F}(\mathrm{~A}): \mathrm{F} \cap \mathrm{I} \neq \varnothing \forall \mathrm{I} \in \mathrm{Z}\}
$$

and $A^{\sigma}$ is isomorphic to the complete lattice $\mathcal{G}(\phi, \psi)$ of Galois closed elements (see [GH01, Prop. 2.6]).
(2) The isomorphism of Theorem 2.7(2) sends $\mathrm{I} \in \mathcal{J A}$ to the open upset

$$
s(I)=\bigcup\{s(a): a \in I\}
$$

Therefore, $s\left(V_{\alpha} I_{\alpha}\right)=\bigcup_{\alpha} s\left(I_{\alpha}\right)$ and $s(I \cap J)=s(I) \cap s(J)$. This will be used in subsequent sections.

To characterize $\mathcal{D} M A$ and $\mathcal{B} \mathcal{L} A$ in terms of the Priestley dual $X$ of $A$, we first recall that $\mathcal{D} M A$ can be constructed as the complete lattice of normal ideals of $A$ and $\mathcal{B} \mathcal{L} A$ as the frame of D-ideals of A (see the beginning of Section 3 for details). Since ideals of A dually correspond to open upsets of $X$, it is sufficient to recognize which open upsets correspond to normal ideals and which to D-ideals.

Consider the following two closure operators on $\operatorname{OpUp}(X)$ : $\operatorname{int}_{1} \mathrm{cl}_{2}$ and $\operatorname{int}_{1} \mathrm{cl}$. Observe that the second one is even a nucleus on $\operatorname{OpUp}(X)$ (see [BH14, Prop. 6.1]).

Definition 2.9. Let $X$ be a Priestley space.
(1) We call a fixpoint of $\operatorname{int}_{1} \mathrm{cl}_{2}$ a Dedekind-MacNeille upset or DM-upset, and let $\operatorname{DM}(X)$ be the poset of DM-upsets of X.
(2) We call a fixpoint of $\operatorname{int}_{1} \mathrm{cl}$ a Bruns-Lakser upset or BL-upset, and let $\mathrm{BL}(\mathrm{X})$ be the poset of BL-upsets of X.

It turns out that normal ideals exactly correspond to DM-upsets, while D-ideals to BLupsets, and hence we obtain:

Theorem 2.10. Let $A \in$ DLat and $X$ be the Priestley space of $A$.
(1) [BH04, Thm. 3.5] $\mathcal{D} M A \cong \operatorname{DM}(X)$.
(2) [BH14, Prop. 6.1, 8.12] $\mathcal{B} \mathcal{L} A \cong B L(X)$.

Remark 2.11. We have the following poset inclusions

$$
L(X) \subseteq \operatorname{DM}(X) \subseteq \operatorname{BL}(X) \subseteq \operatorname{OpUp}(X) \subseteq \operatorname{Up}(X)
$$

most of which are obvious. We only verify that $\operatorname{DM}(X) \subseteq \operatorname{BL}(X)$ : if $U \in \operatorname{DM}(X)$ then $U=\operatorname{int}_{1} \mathrm{cl}_{2}(U)$, so

$$
U \subseteq \operatorname{int}_{1} \mathrm{cl}(U) \subseteq \operatorname{int}_{1} \uparrow \mathrm{cl}(U)=\operatorname{int}_{1} \mathrm{cl}_{2}(U)=U
$$

and hence $U \in \operatorname{BL}(X)$. Moreover, $L(X)$ is a bounded sublattice of each of the four, $\operatorname{DM}(X)$ is a bounded sub- $\cap$-semilattice of $\operatorname{BL}(X), \operatorname{BL}(X)$ is a sublocale ${ }^{3}$ of $\operatorname{OpUp}(X)$, and $\operatorname{OpUp}(X)$ is a subframe of $\operatorname{Up}(X)$. That $\operatorname{BL}(X)$ is a sublocale of $\operatorname{OpUp}(X)$ can be seen by observing that $\operatorname{BL}(X)$ is the fixpoints of the nucleus $\operatorname{int}_{1} \mathrm{cl}$ on $\operatorname{OpUp}(X)$. For the same reason, joins in $\mathrm{BL}(\mathrm{X})$ are calculated by the formula $\bigvee_{\mathrm{BL}(\mathrm{X})} \mathrm{S}=\operatorname{int}_{1} \mathrm{cl}(\bigcup S)$ for each $\mathrm{S} \subseteq \operatorname{OpUp}(\mathrm{X})$. This will be used frequently in subsequent sections.

Remark 2.12. As a consequence of Remark 2.11, we obtain the following poset embeddings

$$
\mathrm{A} \hookrightarrow \mathcal{D} M A \hookrightarrow \mathcal{B} \mathcal{L} A \hookrightarrow \mathcal{J} A \hookrightarrow \mathrm{~A}^{\sigma}
$$

(which can also be proved directly without the use of Priestley duality). Furthermore, A is isomorphic to a bounded sublattice of each of the four, $\mathcal{D} M A$ is isomorphic to a bounded sub- $\wedge$-semilattice of $\mathcal{B} \mathcal{L} A, \mathcal{B} \mathcal{L} A$ is isomorphic to a sublocale of $\mathcal{J} A$, and $\mathcal{J} A$ is isomorphic to a subframe of $A^{\sigma}$. For a direct proof that $\mathcal{B} \mathcal{L} A$ is isomorphic to a sublocale of $\mathcal{J} A$ we refer to [BDRWW24, Thm. 5.17].

Table 1 summarizes the completions of a distributive lattice that will be considered in this paper, together with their representations. The third column provides the ideal representations and the last column the Priestley representations.
